report_title: Cigarette & Tobacco Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Decades of information have drilled the negative health impacts of regular tobacco use into much of the public's mind, causing fewer and fewer younger consumers to pick up the habit and the percentage of smokers to steadily sink. But that doesn't mean sales have steadily sunk. Cigarette and tobacco manufacturers perform countercyclically to the business cycle, benefitting from nicotine, a naturally occurring chemical in tobacco that provides users with a sense of calm and one of the most addictive substances documented.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Tobacco Sales Buck Traditional Retail Trends, Expanding During Uncertain Times
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Cigarettes and tobacco products contain one of the most addictive substances, nicotine, which provides users with, among other sensations, a feeling of calm. During periods of uncertainty, tobacco users increase consumption and former users turn back to such products for relief.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE PERCENTAGE OF SMOKERS CONTINUES ITS DOWNWARD SPIRAL
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: With the negative outcomes of regular tobacco use understood by the general public, the percentage of smokers in the US has been declining for decades. The sinking rate poses a significant threat to producers, particularly down the road, as few are currently able to expand their audience.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: UNFAVORABLE LEGISLATION SPELLS TROUBLE FOR MANUFACTURERS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: For decades, the federal and state governments have passed increasingly restrictive legislation on the sale and advertisement of cigarettes and tobacco products to reduce the rate of younger generations becoming addicted to such products.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE PRODUCTS WILL SIPHON MORE SALES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Smokers will increasingly turn to electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) and other vape products to kick the habit of traditional combustible cigarette use in the coming years, siphoning producers' main source of revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: PRODUCERS WILL SHIFT FOCUS TO HIGHLIGHT FORMERLY ANCILLARY PRODUCTS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To combat the negative associations encouraged by anti-smoking campaigns and rising e-cigarette popularity, manufacturers will develop new products with fewer health risks and less accompanying social stigma.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE INTERNATIONAL MARKET WILL PROVIDE FEW OPTIONS FOR GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Exports will continue accounting for a small share of revenue as manufacturers struggle to branch into foreign markets where other brands already have a major hold on the market.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry manufacture cigarettes, cigars, loose pipe tobacco and smokeless (i.e. chewing) tobacco. Tobacco manufacturers acquire raw materials from tobacco growers, paper and fiber manufacturers, tobacco stemmers and tobacco redryers and process these into ready-to-use products sold to wholesalers and retailers.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level high - increasing

key_trends: Manufacturers contend with an ever-shrinking market. Older smokers who show no signs of quitting are willing to roll with growing prices, enabling producers to generate substantial profit and mitigate revenue losses. But the percentage of smokers is steadily shrinking.

Electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) are siphoning away potential and current customers. E-cigarettes appeal to young consumers and smokers seeking a method to quit, which ends up hurting cigarette producers twofold, as they risk losing current customers and potential customers.
The industry is heavily regulated. Tobacco products are closely monitored by the FDA and other government bodies. Manufacturers also face advertising restrictions.
Tariffs provide domestic operators with breathing room. Imports are subject to heavy tariffs, preventing foreign operators from gaining footholds in domestic markets.

Cigarettes remain the biggest source of revenue. With bans on menthol cigarettes beginning to emerge and traditional cigarettes falling further out of fashion, producers need to invest in external products, like e-cigarettes, and invest in new product lines.

Many retailers stop selling or reduce tobacco product stock. Big-brand retailers, like pharmacies and supermarkets, are continually pulling away from selling tobacco products, leaving convenience stores to lap up the abandoned market.
Manufacturers will locate near tobacco farmers, the industry's largest input. Tobacco farmers are almost exclusively located in the Southeast region.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Cigarette and tobacco product wholesalers consist of national and regional distributors of tobacco products, snacks and confectioneries to convenience stores, dollar stores, pharmacies and other related retail channels.

Gas stations and convenience stores include gas stations with convenience stores and stand-alone convenience stores. According to a 2017 study, nearly 70.0% of smokers purchased cigarettes and other tobacco products from gas stations and convenience stores.

Convenience stores typically maintain longer hours of operation than larger retailers, like grocery stores or pharmacies, and are usually located in convenience locations, like on the side of major highways and near other retailers.
Tobacco and cigarette producers also sell to a range of wholesalers and retailers, like grocery wholesalers, supermarkets and pharmacies. However, such channels are shrinking as a share of revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: Smokeless tobacco products include chewing and spitting tobacco, snuff and snus. Snuff is made from finely ground tobacco leaves, whereas snus is moist powdered tobacco consumed under the lip.
The term "cigar" denotes a broad category of smokable tobacco products ranging from little machine-made cigars (cigarillos) to imported, handmade cigars sold at a premium price.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Manufacturers can generate higher revenue in major cities. Many manufacturers have operations in the Mid-Atlantic and West regions near major cities like New York City, Philadelphia and Los Angeles.
Consumers display strong brand loyalty, making it difficult to sway existing companies from a particular brand. Manufacturers can easily raise the price of tobacco products without dips in demand.
Manufacturers have faced declining demand for their products. These companies must contend with heavy competition from e-cigarette companies and smoking cessation products.
Major companies dominate the industry. The three largest players make up more than 65.0% of the total market.
Manufacturers are diversifying. As the traditional cigarette business grows unprofitable, major companies have made investments in e-cigarette companies and nicotine-quitting replacements.
The industry grapples with significant legal fees. Manufacturers are subject to heavy ongoing litigation fees and ongoing payments to signatories.
Manufacturers maintain a massive profit margin. Companies can easily pass excise taxes, litigation costs and other fees onto consumers, given the addictive nature of the industry's products.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Consumers Increasingly Seek Out Premium, Hand-Rolled Cigars From Renowned Regions

While domestic consumers have historically displayed a penchant for certain foreign tobacco products, like premium cigars or specialty cigarettes, imported products account for a relatively low share of domestic demand.
Exports account for less than 1.0% of domestic cigarette and tobacco producers' revenue, so fluctuations in international markets have a modest impact on the average manufacturer.

The biggest importers of domestic cigarettes and tobacco products are the Dominican Republic and Canada, which have both historically accounted for a sizable chunk of exports; however, the standard allocation of exported tobacco products has been shifting.

business_locations.location_description: The industry is heavily concentrated in the Southeast. The region's share of establishments is nearly double the region's population share. Nearly all tobacco farmers are in the Southeast region, enabling manufacturers to build relationships and source inexpensive materials from key suppliers.

Manufacturers also have quick access to major population centers, like New York City, Philadelphia and Jersey City. Young people, aged 25 to 44, are among the highest smoking demographic. Large cities attract more young people, especially those with high-stress

California accounts for the second-highest number of establishments in the country. As with the Mid-Atlantic region, the West has many heavily populated cities, making it a prime target for manufacturers. The region also facilitates trade through Latin American countries and Canada. Even so, the total trade volume is extremely low, limiting new opportunities.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: In 2009, the US Congress approved legislation that permits the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to regulate cigarettes and other tobacco products in the United States. Known as the Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act, the law bans flavored cigarettes (excluding menthol cigarettes), which appeal to younger people.

regulations_points.regulation_title: ALCOHOL AND TOBACCO TAX AND TRADE BUREAU
regulations_points.regulation_description: The US Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) operated under the Department of the Treasury and was established in 2002 under the Homeland Security Act. The bureau reviews applications for permits to manufacture tobacco products, import tobacco products and operate tobacco export warehouses.

The Federal Trade Commission enforces the Federal Comprehensive Smoking Education Act (1984) and the Federal Comprehensive Smokeless Tobacco Health Education Act (1986). These acts require manufacturers to place specific warning labels on cigarette and smokeless tobacco packages.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline stage.
Competition level is high and increasing.

factors_increased_barrier: The largest producers have been in the game for decades and use advanced automated systems to reduce operational costs. New entrants must invest heavily in capital expenses to maintain competitive prices.
factors_decreased_barrier: Globalization level is low and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Consumers display strong brand loyalty, making it difficult to sway existing companies from a particular brand.
Manufacturers can easily raise the price of tobacco products without dips in demand.
Manufacturers have faced declining demand for their products. These companies must contend with heavy competition from e-cigarette companies and smoking cessation products.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Market share has historically fluctuated annually, but the largest manufacturers have dominated the field for some time. Though most are older businesses benefitting from brand loyalty, acquiring smaller brands has become one of the only viable options for expansion.
The three largest cigarette and tobacco producers generate nearly three-quarters of revenue.
Rising barriers to entry and an increasingly stringent regulatory framework prevent smaller companies from entering the industry or gaining a meaningful market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rising Purchase Costs Do Little to Hinder Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Cigarette and tobacco product manufacturers require various inputs for final products, including tobacco leaves, paper, additives, cellulose materials and packaging. More than any other input, tobacco leaf is vital for production and typically accounts for the bulk of purchase costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: An Inability to Market Products Leaves Cigarette Producers Clinging to a Shrinking Base
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As part of the Final Tobacco Marketing Rule, legislation has effectively prohibited tobacco-affiliated businesses from engaging in traditional advertising methods, including outdoor billboards, TV or radio commercials and attractive product packaging. Instead, companies rely on existing branding to facilitate sales.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: OTHER COSTS MOUNT AMID HEAVY LITIGATION COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: This segment includes several expense categories unique to the tobacco industry, including federal excise taxes, tobacco-related litigation costs and ongoing payments to the signatories of the 1998 Master Settlement Agreement (MSA).

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The largest producers have been in the game for decades and use advanced automated systems to reduce operational costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: New entrants must invest heavily in capital expenses
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: New entrants must invest heavily in capital expenses to maintain competitive prices.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low threat of new technologies driving disruption
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Cigarette and Tobacco Products' Addictive Nature Can Limit and Boost Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Tobacco products are unique in that they contain nicotine, a highly addictive chemical. Consumers are typically either addicted to tobacco products and willing to purchase them regardless of economic situations, addicted to nicotine but refraining from using nicotine-containing products or have never used tobacco products.
The key distinguishing feature between cigarettes and cigars is that the former is wrapped using paper, while the latter is wrapped with rolled tobacco leaves.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Mounting Health Awareness and Expanding Regulations Pose Uncertainty
volatility_points.volatility_description: Health concerns and government regulations constantly threaten the stability of cigarette and tobacco product manufacturer's operations.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Cigarettes Remain Producers' Primary Revenue Stream
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The cigarette segment is divided into menthol and nonmenthol (regular) cigarettes. Almost all cigarettes today contain menthol, but only those with more than 0.1% menthol by weight are classified as menthol cigarettes.

Menthol cigarettes are disproportionately prevalent among younger adults and inexperienced smokers. Federal tobacco-related legislation has yet to target mentholated cigarettes specifically; however, certain states have begun banned menthol cigarettes in recent years.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Smokeless Tobacco Appeal Grows in Specific Markets
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Smokeless tobacco products include chewing and spitting tobacco, snuff and snus. Snuff is made from finely ground tobacco leaves, whereas snus is moist powdered tobacco consumed under the lip.

FAQs.question: How does your company respond to import competition?
FAQs.answer: Cigarette and tobacco manufacturers respond to import competition by improving their product quality, enhancing their brand image and investing in extensive marketing campaigns. They also adapt to competition by introducing innovative products, reducing prices strategically and entering into strategic partnerships or mergers with international brands.

FAQs.question: Are your company's cigarette and tobacco sales significantly impacted by volatile economic conditions?
FAQs.answer: While a healthy US economy benefits manufacturers, demand for their products can withstand periods of poor economic performance. This can even accelerate demand because of heightened stress.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuations in the price of tobacco and other key inputs impact your operations?
FAQs.answer: The world price of tobacco (the industry's biggest input) has endured significant volatility. Regardless, tobacco consumers are typically unfazed by price changes, as solid brand loyalty and the addictive nature of tobacco products keep long-time smoker demand high.

FAQs.question: Does your company strategically establish operations close to upstream suppliers?
FAQs.answer: The Southeast region is the most popular region for manufacturers because of the abundance of tobacco farms and the ease of obtaining inputs.

FAQs.question: How has your company adapted to new technologies producing increasingly popular substitute products like e-cigarettes?
FAQs.answer: Most major cigarette and tobacco manufacturers have begun manufacturing or have acquired at least one brand of e-cigarettes, as health concerns drive many would-be smokers to take up e-cigarettes instead of traditional combustible cigarettes. While these developments have helped companies' overall performance, e-cigarettes are not industry-relevant. They have not assisted companies' industry-relevant performance.

FAQs.question: How have emerging technological innovations allowed your company to reduce reliance on a traditional workforce and reduce wage costs?
FAQs.answer: Automation has been used heavily by cigarette and tobacco manufacturers for decades, keeping wage costs significantly lower than in many other manufacturing industries.

FAQs.question: Have regulatory changes impacted cigarette and tobacco manufacturers' profit?
FAQs.answer: Regulatory changes like higher excise taxes, implemented in many countries, have reduced demand for tobacco products, thereby impacting cigarette and tobacco manufacturers' profit. Stringent marketing and advertising restrictions have limited manufacturers' ability to promote their products, potentially reducing sales and impacting profit.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay abreast of regulatory changes in an industry increasingly scrutinized by regulatory bodies?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers receive assistance in dealing with the heavily regulated environment through industry associations, like the Tobacco Merchants Association.

FAQs.question: How has your company's profit performance compared with the industry's largest manufacturers?
FAQs.answer: The industry's most prominent companies regularly report double-digit profit with little deterring growth.

FAQs.question: Do fluctuations in input costs have a significant effect on your profit?
FAQs.answer: Input prices do not strongly impact industry profit. Thus, while the world price of tobacco (the industry's key input) has fluctuated, companies have endured, as price hikes are not a significant deterrent for their customers.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? How do you compete with historically large companies that do successfully leverage economies of scale?
FAQs.answer: A few large companies dominate the industry, benefiting from and leveraging economies of scale to maintain their hold on the industry. Due to the dropping demand for tobacco products and the strong market grasp by the industry's largest manufacturers, it's difficult for new companies to carve a path.

FAQs.question: What is your marketing strategy to attract customers to products that carry clear and significant consequences to users' health? Do you find new marketing avenues difficult since many have been closed off to tobacco producers?
FAQs.answer: Many manufacturers have increasingly diversified their product portfolio to include more smokeless products, and the consequences of combustible cigarettes have deterred many new smokers. Still, many noncombustible substitute products, including increasingly popular e-cigarette products, are not industry-relevant.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost hikes, mainly in the form of rising excise taxes, to your customers? How do you attempt to keep costs mitigated amid the dropping demand for cigarettes?
FAQs.answer: Stemming from a boost in excise taxes and a drop in demand for tobacco products, the leading producers have pushed up their product prices to maintain earnings. While the swelling prices often deter new smokers, addicted, life-long smokers are willing to pay for the same product.

FAQs.question: As the percentage of smokers continues to drop, how has your company marketed its products in light of the growing stigma against tobacco? What alternative products do you offer?
FAQs.answer: Operators investing in a diverse range of substitute products will be best equipped to adapt to an environment of fewer and fewer smokers.

FAQs.question: How have swelling excise taxes on tobacco products impacted your sales volumes? Can you generate sufficient revenue from selling lower volumes at higher prices?
FAQs.answer: A boost in excise tax on tobacco products results in higher selling prices, deterring many casual or prospective smokers. Nicotine is highly addictive; long-time smokers are less deterred by high prices and will pay more for the same product.

FAQs.question: The price of industry goods has increased consistently for decades. How have rising selling prices affected demand for your company's goods? Does your product portfolio include a range of price points?
FAQs.answer: Companies with a diverse product portfolio covering a range of price points are best equipped to handle shifting disposable income levels. A boost in disposable income typically results in higher sales of premium products and lower demand for bargain brands.
